Title:
Metarhizium protaetiae sp. nov.: a cryptic species of
Metarhizium majus and a fruit beetle grub pathogen
Keywords:
Metarhizium majus; Scarabaeidae; phylogenetic analysis;
pathogenicity; intergenic spacer region; cryptic species
Abstract:
Metarhizium majus (or M. anisopliae var. majus) has long
been known as a specialist pathogen of Scarabaeidae species. Some
studies have revealed that each isolate of M. majus from different host
species adapts to its own host and has a different host range. However,
the intraspecific phylogenetic relationships of this species have never
been investigated. In this study, we compared phylogenetic relationships
and pathogenicity among strains of M. majus including an isolate from a
fruit beetle grub (Protaetia orientalis) (Hn1), which was
morphologically identified as M. majus. As a result of phylogenetic
analysis of the ribosomal DNA intergenic spacer region, the obtained
genealogy was clearly related with the host taxon. In the phylogeny, Hn1
was placed distantly from the strains originating from other scarabaidae
species and grouped with two Japanese strains from soil. Regarding
pathogenicity, only Hn1 and the two Japanese strains caused the mycosis
of the larvae of P. orientalis, although it is difficult to distinguish
the three strains from the other M. majus strains based on morphological
characteristics. From these results, we concluded that Hn1 is a cryptic
species of M. majus and proposed M. protaetiae sp. nov. to accommodate
these isolates.
